Review.title: Would love to use it all the time, but can't
Review.comment: I've been using Tweet Lanes for about a month and like the design and what the developer is trying to do. If you just want to use it to look at your timeline, view your profile and your tweets/retweets/mentions then this will work for you. Unfortunately I use lists to manage Twitter, and this app is very inconsistent with this functionality. Sometimes I can go to the settings and see my lists and add them in to the main app. Then the lists disappear from the main app and when I go into settings, they have disappeared from there too, so I can add them back in. This happens daily. I also can't seem to add or manage those lists from the app, so afraid I'm back to my unsupported Falcon Pro app for Twitter for now.

Review.title: Was 4-stars but now 3. Why? TweetSpotlight
Review.comment: The UI is very clean and well thought out. It's the best Twitter client I've found so far for handling Twitter lists. I really enjoyed it when I first tried it out. However I tend to read through my timeline quickly and add articles to Pocket for reading later. In Seesmic, I could just long-press on a link and immediately send to Pocket. With TweetLanes, it took 2 clicks but I could deal. But with the newest update and a new screen called TweetSpotlight, I need to long-press (for what seems like a really long time) in order to see the Share option. And sometimes the long-press doesn't fire and I have to retry. It's irksome and perhaps a deal breaker.

It only stores Tweets in cache from the last update. So if you use an underground subway or don't have service for part of your commute, you won't be able to ready your full Twitter history, only the Tweets since your last refresh. Add these two features and my 3 stars becomes 5 stars without question.

There should be an option to choose the link you want like in Plume or my favorite Twitter client Twicca, which this app reminds me of. On the plus side, this app is beautiful and I love the constant text box at the bottom, which enables quick commenting. I also enjoy the Jellybean look. Profile pages are also beautiful. Please keep up the good work. This is a wonderful app.

It's not exactly "buttery smooth" on my GNex running 4.1.1, but nothing debilitating. Great job so far; looking forward to future dev's.

Great start, hopefully Twitter doesn't destroy the API's for 3rd parties but let's hope for the best. Future suggestions: Tweetmarker, landscape keyboard, drafts, Readability/Pocket/Instapaper support within the TL, add/remove users from lists, perhaps a mobilized (Readability/Instapaper) version of a link just to name a couple. Some of those I'm sure are already on deck but still worth mentioning.

Review.author: A Google User
Review.star: Rated 4 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Good start, features missing.
Review.comment: Good start, it's not the first ICS style twitter app, but it does it the best out of the lot, not quite ready to be a daily driver though, few key features are missing: No log out option? Layout of the the drop down at the top doesn't display too well - big margins? Icon isn't too great. Custom font size - I want to see more tweets without scrolling. Landscape mode? - or at least for when composing a new tweet, for a bigger keyboard? Better tablet support - Columns in a landscape mode would be nice. Widget Dark theme Muting Good points: Introduction slides where good, friendly and well done. ICS design executed perfectly - big plus! Unique features that make sense. Everything that works, seems to work well. Looking forward to seeing what comes of this, if these problems get fixed quick, I can see it becoming the top twitter client of choice :)

Review.author: A Google User
Review.star: Rated 4 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Could finally replace tweetdeck for me
Review.comment: This seems like a great start so far, with an obviously still in development app. I've been looking for something clean and simple to replace tweetdeck for awhile, but nothing exists out there where I can use multiple accounts, choose columns, and not look completely terrible. I really think this might end up being it, since the visual style is great, the lanes are essentially like tweetdeck columns, and it has multiple account support. A killer feature going forwards would be allowing mixed lanes with the multiple account support instead of having to context switch the app between accounts. That, and the ability to pick which account to tweet FROM on the fly are the features that keep me going back to tweetdeck, so I'd love to see them in a slick app like this one.

Review.author: A Google User
Review.star: Rated 4 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Great early start - interface looks ICSdelicious
Review.comment: Great early start - here's my positives, followed by a wishlist for features: Positives: Super fast, nice switching mechanism, love the multiple select options, love the quick access to lists and favourites (something the stock official app makes hard to find), beautiful ICS official look to it all, love the inline images + vid options. Bonus: hasn't crashed or stalled once yet even with heavy use and fast screen switching etc, with one exception (see below) Wishlist/Comments: Can't figure out how to view a conversation (@ reply flow), can't figure out how to add an image or vid to a tweet, would like to see the android ICS dark theme as well as the stock light theme, Didn't like app icon being put on my screen automatically (I have that disabled - how did the app get around it?), needs Settings available soon for img hosting options, notifications, all the usual stuff. When sending img from gallery, it just goes to a black screen, so a bug or something (pulling img from google cloud); also, would like landscape view (split screen maybe?)
